content.description:
This climbs the side of Easter Rock that faces towards Keyhole Rock.  Climb a steep, unprotected face on loose edges to a large shelf.  Walk up the shelf to the base of the summit ridge, and climb a little more steep rock to the top.  Not much gear, and what there is won't do you a lot of good.  Still, not a terrible climb, and you bag a summit with a good view of the rest of the garden.

Addendum: There are 2 starts to this climb.  You can start West Face Left, 5.5 R/X, or West Face Right, 5.5 R/X.  It is best to consider this a solo.
content.protection: Not much.  You might be able to place tricams in potholes or loop a boulder with a long piece of webbing.  There is a fixed rap anchor on top.

content.description: This is a fun route up the blunt south ridge of Easter Rock.  It is fairly steep and climbs a little harder than it might look from the ground, with interesting moves over 2 bulges.  If just clipping the pins, it might feel a bit spicy, but some Camalots will help with this.
content.protection: 3 drilled pins.  2 new bolts and 2 pins for the chain anchor.  You can also place a #0.5 & #0.75 Camalot if needed.
content.location: This route follows the blunt south ridge directly up to the summit.  Rappel off the west face.

content.description: Follow the blunt north ridge through several overhanging potholes with big holds.  The crux was about 15 feet off the ground with a long reach to a pretty good left hand in a hole, sloping feet underneath the overhang, and not much for the right hand.  Once past this crux, the difficulty quickly eases off for the rest of the climb to the top.
content.protection: I did not see any fixed protection, and the holds look pretty worn -- I recommend top roping it using the highest of the two bolts on the north side of the rock as a directional.
content.location: The route follows overhanging potholes up the north ridge (arete) of Easter Rock.  Rappel from a good set of anchors with a chain put up by Stewart Green.

content.description: This is a toprope line on the left side of the west face, more or less directly under the summit anchor. The crux is surmounting the bulge on friable edges and shallow pockets below the large ledge.
content.protection: Set up a TR at the summit anchors after ascending one of the other protectable routes on the formation.
